meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>shellfish</radical> has a <radical>knife</radical> in its <kanji>side</kanji>. It's fine though, don't worry, it's just a reminder that he won the great shellfish war back when they were trying to choose the new leader.
meaning_hint: Picture the shellfish leader in your mind and make sure to pay special attention to the knife that's sticking out of his side. It's right in the groove of his shell.
reading_mnemonic: Because of this knife in his <kanji>side</kanji>, he can't pronounce certain words correctly. The most obvious one is when he says <reading>川</reading> (かわ), but it comes out of the side of his mouth as がわ.
reading_hint: Try saying かわ out the side of your mouth like the leader of the shellfish and you'll probably say がわ too. Don't stick a knife in your side though, we won't pay your medical bills when you complain to us that this mnemonic got you injured.

meaning_mnemonic: If you set a fish on the <radical>ground</radical> and chop its <radical>fins</radical> off with an <radical>axe</radical>, you’re probably a <kanji>soldier</kanji>. Only soldiers have access to axes, and you like to eat fish, but first you have to set it on the ground to chop its fins off.
meaning_hint: Imagine trying to carve a fish with an axe. Probably not an easy thing to do. If you’re a trained axe soldier, you’d probably have an easier time with it. Picture yourself chopping off fins as an expert axe soldier.
reading_mnemonic: Uh-oh, it looks like this axe <kanji>soldier</kanji> was so excited about chopping the fins off his fish that he didn't think about how he was going to cook them. The only thing nearby to light on fire is a bale of <reading>hay</reading> (へい). Well, it's not the best thing, but at least it will get these fish cooked.
reading_hint: Imagine this soldier lighting a bale of hay on fire to cook his fish. The hay burns really fast, but it should be enough.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tiger</radical> kills a <radical>pig</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> in this new <kanji>drama</kanji> about the animal kingdom! The tiger and pig used to be friends when they were younger, but now they're bitter enemies and the tiger just stabbed the pig right in the chest with a knife.
meaning_hint: Picture this scene from the drama as dramatically as you can. The pig stares into the tiger's eyes, "Tiger, you wouldn't–uh!" The pig's eyes slowly lower to see the knife sticking into its gut, the tiger's hand still holding it. "This is what you get, you pig," the tiger spits back, twisting.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>drama</kanji> is being put on by <reading>Gecki</reading> (げき), your childhood pet gecko. Gecki is playing all the parts, because as true drama fans know, one-gecko-shows are the highest form of art.
reading_hint: Picture Gecki acting out the part of the tiger and the pig in this drama. It's so intense, you're moved to tears. Bravo Gecki, bravo!

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>original</radical> radical and the <kanji>original</kanji> kanji are the same!

This kanji can also mean <kanji>field</kanji>, probably because that's what everything originally looked like before humans: just a bunch of fields.
meaning_hint: Know your radicals! I shouldn't even have to tell you this by now.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> Japanese hero was <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん), from "The Tale of Genji."
reading_hint: Picture Genji, the original Japanese protagonist, walking through the streets. He's signing his name for swooning ladies and gentlemen. Genji is the OG (original Genji).

meaning_mnemonic: If there is a <radical>drum</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> it's time to <kanji>rejoice</kanji>! And because of your mouth drum your rejoicing will be loud and booming!
meaning_hint: Imagine having a drum in your mouth and rejoicing about it! Imagine how loud it would be!
reading_mnemonic: You loudly <kanji>rejoice</kanji> for a while when suddenly someone runs over and shoves a <reading>key</reading> (き) in your mouth, locking it shut. You can't rejoice anymore! You need that key to unlock your mouth!
reading_hint: Imagine if people could just stop the rejoicing of others by locking their mouths shut with keys. What a sad world.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>big</radical> <radical>mouth</radical> is the <kanji>cause</kanji> of all your problems.
meaning_hint: Imagine all the dumb things you blabber about with your mouth open big and wide. Saying things you shouldn't say... causing drama and stuff. Shame on you.
reading_mnemonic: Your big mouth <kanji>cause</kanji>s all of your friends and family to move to an <reading>inn</reading> (いん) so they don't have to live near you and hear you talk anymore.
reading_hint: Who knew you could cause people to live in an inn instead of their own homes with your big mouth...

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> will empty his <radical>mouth</radical> of all its <radical>dirt</radical> in the great <kanji>hall</kanji>. They all get together in some kind of <kanji>public chamber</kanji> and dish all the dirt (literal and figurative) that they've got.
meaning_hint: Picture a long Viking hall, with a big table and tons of chairs. All of the Vikings are gossiping and sharing all their dirt on their enemies.
reading_mnemonic: While the Vikings gather to spill the dirt in their <kanji>hall</kanji>, they also stuff their faces with <reading>dou</reading>ghnuts (どう). Ah yes, Vikings love to eat doughnuts when they talk trash.
reading_hint: Now picture all of the Vikings in the hall spitting dirt with one breath and shoveling doughnuts in with the next. It's pretty gross!

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>dirt</radical>, there's a <radical>gun</radical>. Its <radical>mouth</radical> points toward a <radical>plate</radical>. What's on the plate? Why, it's <kanji>salt</kanji>!
meaning_hint: In olden days, salt was so valuable it was used as money. So imagine the gun buried in the dirt, its mouth vigilantly guarding the plate of salt.
reading_mnemonic: When you see the <kanji>salt</kanji>, you think to yourself, "<reading>She owe</reading>s (しお) me big time, so I'm going to go ahead and snatch her salt!" Who is she, you ask? She's the lady who owns the salt. And the gun in the dirt, of course.
reading_hint: Are you sure you want to take her salt? Sure, she owes you, but I don't think you want to argue with the mouth of a gun.

meaning_mnemonic: Under this <radical>roof</radical> is a <radical>bear</radical> who works for the <kanji>government</kanji>. If you saw a bear out in the wild you might be afraid and try to run, but if you see a bear inside a building under a roof, don't be scared! It's just a government bear.
meaning_hint: Picture the government bear looking through government documents and snorting gruffly as it decides what to sign and what to reject. It has a little government sash and hat.
reading_mnemonic: The first <kanji>government</kanji> that allowed bears was set up by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん). He was all about conquering people and then using them as efficiently as possible. He discovered that bears are incredibly useful in government buildings as government workers.
reading_hint: Picture Genghis Khan patting the first bear government worker on the back as they start their first day working for the government.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're on the <radical>roof</radical> of the <radical>festival</radical> you'll have to <kanji>guess</kanji> what's actually going on below you. You can kind of see that there are rides and maybe food? It smells like food. But you have to guess on the specifics because you're above it and not in it.
meaning_hint: Imagine being on the roof above a festival. Can you guess what's happening below you based on the sounds and smells?
reading_mnemonic: To get a better <kanji>guess</kanji>, you ask <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ) for help. She's that little girl you know from some earlier mnemonics, and she happens to be up on the roof with you. Picture her as you ask, "What's your guess, Satsuki?"
reading_hint: And what's Satsuki doing up here, anyway? Your guess is as good as mine. Now imagine you and her trying to guess what kind of festival it is.

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>yurt</radical> you use a <radical>towel</radical> as a <kanji>seat</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Picture this yurt, with towels laid out as seats for everyone who visits.
reading_mnemonic: Something about using a towel for a <kanji>seat</kanji> is very <reading>sexy</reading> (せき) to you. Probably because you associate it with sexy people using towel seats on the beach.
reading_hint: Imagine the sexiest person you've ever seen, using a towel as a seat next to you in this yurt. Maybe they're in a bathing suit. Maybe they're completely covered up. Either way, they're very sexy.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>viking</radical> with a <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>towel</radical> is a totally <kanji>normal</kanji> thing. It's <kanji>ordinary</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Vikings get a lot of nasty stuff on their mouths from their messy eating and pillaging, so it makes sense that they'd all have mouth towels. It's as ordinary and normal as it gets, at least amongst the vikings.
reading_mnemonic: It's <kanji>normal</kanji> for a viking to have a mouth towel, but your sloppy farmhand friend <reading>Joe</reading>(じょう) has a mouth towel too. That's a habit that's only <kanji>normal</kanji> for vikings, so why does he have one?
reading_hint: When you ask Joe about his Viking mouth towel, he just tells you, "It's normal for everyone to have mouth towels. Totally ordinary." Now that you think about it, he really is a messy dude, so he probably needs it.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dry</radical> radical and the <kanji>dry</kanji> kanji are the same!
meaning_hint: Know your radicals, yo!
reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>dry</kanji> Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん). He hates being wet, all of the Mongols do, so your job is to dry his entire body. And his clothes, and his horse. In fact, when it rains, you have to ride next to him keeping him dry by holding an umbrella above his head.
reading_hint: Imagine keeping Genghis Khan completely dry all day every day. He won't even get wet to bathe. Instead he makes you rub his body with dry sand and salts.

meaning_mnemonic: You hide <radical>poop</radical> in a <radical>cape</radical> as part of the <kanji>illusion</kanji> in your magic show. Your acts are kind of gross and this one involves creating the illusion of disappearing poop by hiding it within the folds of your cape.
meaning_hint: Imagine having poop in your cape. It would smell bad and anyone close to you would be able to smell right through the illusion.
reading_mnemonic: Somehow the poop cape <kanji>illusion</kanji> goes over really well. The crowd is giving you a standing ovation and right in the center is <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん). He marches up to you, wipes a tear from his eye, and says, "Your illusion cape is wonderful. I must have it!"
reading_hint: Genji grabs the cape before you can stop him and he puts it on. You can see the illusion fade, he keeps smiling but more tears start streaming down his face. "A wonderful illusion, the best I've ever seen," he chokes out and marches away, without looking back.

meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>canopy</radical> your <radical>clan</radical> digs in the <radical>ground</radical>, trying to get to the <kanji>bottom</kanji>. They want to build a nice home your entire clan can live in, but they need to get to the bottom before they'll start building.
meaning_hint: Picture all of the people in your clan under this canopy digging with all their might, trying to find the bottom. "Isn't there... no bottom though?" you think to yourself.
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly someone down in the hole shouts that they've reached the <kanji>bottom</kanji>, but it's full of water and they're all <reading>soak</reading>ed (そこ)!
reading_hint: The bottom is full of water, and everyone and everything down there is soaked through now.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Again</radical> and again, your <radical>heart</radical> comes back to the same person. Is this <kanji>romance</kanji>? Are you in <kanji>love</kanji>?
meaning_hint: Perhaps you have a person in mind that your heart comes back to again and again. Associate that person with this notion and kanji, and this'll be easy to memorize!
reading_mnemonic: But, remember that your <kanji>romance</kanji> isn’t a <reading>ren</reading>tal (れん). You really wanna reserve it for the right person!
reading_hint: Don’t let your love become a rental. Wait for the right person to come around.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>criminal</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical> will always be <kanji>sad</kanji>. No one chooses a life of crime if they're happy. And even if they seem like they're doing fine on the outside, deep down they're really sad.
meaning_hint: Imagine watching a criminal after he's done stealing from a bank. He's all alone. He stops throwing the money around. And cries. So so sad.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sad</kanji> feelings fill the criminal's body with <reading>he</reading>at (ひ). This heat spreads and radiates out. If you walk next to them on the street, you'll feel the sad heat floating by you.
reading_hint: Imagine being so sad that your entire body fills with heat. That heat even makes squiggly heat lines pop out above and around you.

meaning_mnemonic: Putting on <radical>cleat</radical>s in the <radical>heart</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> and braving the harsh elements just to plant a kiss on your sweetheart's <radical>forehead</radical> – that's <kanji>love</kanji>. Sure, you could see them another day, but you need to plant this smooch on their forehead today, so you get some cleats for better grip on the winter snow and you keep thoughts of your dear in your heart as you travel to see your love.
meaning_hint: Feel the joy of love in your heart as you travel out in the winter. It’s cold outside, but the feeling of love in your heart keeps you warm. Feel this warm love emanating and heating your body.
reading_mnemonic: Walking through the winter snows with your cleats on, you’ve gotta keep your <reading>eye</reading> (あい) on the prize. It’s a really hard journey, but you keep your eye on the prize, which is your <kanji>love</kanji> and the time you’ll get to spend with them.
reading_hint: Imagine seeing your love with your own two eyes after a long time away from them. It feels great to be reunited and see eye to eye once again. Imagine this feeling.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>shellfish</radical> that can't live through <radical>winter</radical> is a <kanji>failure</kanji>. Any proper shellfish would survive through the winter, so this is quite an embarrassing <kanji>defeat</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine you're a shellfish in the cold, cold winter. The water is freezing but you must tough it out so no one will say you're a failure in spring when they find your dead, defeated shellfish body.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to avoid <kanji>failure</kanji> is to say a little <reading>hai</reading>ku (はい) to distract you from the cold. In fact, this can work in any situation where you're afraid of defeat. Say a haiku aloud, it will calm your nerves and warm you from the inside.
reading_hint: Imagine being a shellfish freezing in the cold winter water, but you avoid failure by muttering haiku over and over to keep you warm and determined.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is <radical>correct</radical>, <kanji>absolutely</kanji>. The mighty sun is never wrong. It is absolutely correct, always.
meaning_hint: Imagine the sun in the sky. Its rays blind you as it corrects all of the errors you’ve made.
reading_mnemonic: Then, a <reading>ze</reading>ppelin (ぜ) flies in front of the sun, blocking it out. <kanji>Absolutely</kanji>, the sun cannot ignore this transgression. Therefore, the sun corrects the zeppelin’s evil ways by frying it with sunshine and bringing it to the ground.
reading_hint: Imagine the sun being so absolutely consumed with rage that it catches a zeppelin on fire and crashes it. Feel the heat from the grounded zeppelin as it smolders.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fruit</radical> radical and the <kanji>fruit</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Bodacious!
reading_mnemonic: They sell <kanji>fruit</kanji> at the store, and you need to drive your <reading>ca</reading>r (か) to get there. A car is the fastest way to fruit.
reading_hint: Imagine you have a hankering for your favorite fruit. You gotta get in your car and put the pedal to the metal! Feel the wind in your hair as your car speeds down the road and listen to that engine purr.

meaning_mnemonic: Aiming your <radical>gun</radical> out the <radical>window</radical>, you shoot at a <radical>tree</radical> filled with <kanji>ume</kanji>, <kanji>Japanese plum</kanji>s. This is, in your opinion, the best way to harvest the plums – shooting at them out your window with a gun.
meaning_hint: Imagine picking fruit off an ume tree in this way – shooting them off the branches with your gun. Picture yourself aiming at the fruits as you hear the gunshots ring in your ears and the smell of gunpowder fills the air.
reading_mnemonic: You’ve probably heard of <kanji>ume</kanji> before, depending on your exposure to Japan, but an <reading>ume</reading> (うめ) is a <kanji>Japanese plum</kanji>.
reading_hint: Imagine eating your harvest of ume. Taste the ripe fruity flesh of these Japanese plums as you stuff your gluttonous face.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming, and you want to <radical>walk</radical> over it, so you have to <kanji>ford</kanji> it. You don’t walk across a tsunami, you <kanji>wade</kanji> across it.
meaning_hint: Imaging taking your shoes off, hiking up your pants, and holding all of your things above your head as you ford across the tsunami.
reading_mnemonic: Your ability to <kanji>ford</kanji> this tsunami impresses everyone who witnesses it, especially the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). Now that you've taught him a tsunami can be forded, he's going to start sending his troops through them instead of waiting for them to pass.
reading_hint: Your new fording techniques have increased the Shougun's military power! Congrats, I guess.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>nothing</radical> radical and the <kanji>nothing</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Woah!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Nothing</kanji> can <reading>moo</reading> (む) quite like a cow can moo. Cows are the best at going moo. That’s a fact.
reading_hint: Listen to this cow moo. Can you do a better moo than this moo cow? Nope.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>rice paddy</radical> that's like a <radical>thread</radical> is extremely <kanji>thin</kanji>, but also <kanji>detailed</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Imagine a rice paddy in the form of an extremely thin, but also detailed piece of thread. The size and detailing means you'd maybe be able to get one line of rice in there? Seems very inefficient.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>thin</kanji> rice paddy is for your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). You only gave your cyborg a really thin strip of human stomach, so it only needs a thin line of rice to eat.
reading_hint: Picture the cyborg eating a really thin piece of rice. Now it's completely full! What a smart, thrifty cyborg!

meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>thread</radical> for <radical>good luck</radical> by <kanji>bind</kanji>ing two fingers together. You <kanji>tie</kanji> them nice and tight.
meaning_hint: Tying two fingers together with a good luck thread is very common where you're from.
reading_mnemonic: After you <kanji>bind</kanji> your fingers, the good luck starts pouring in. Literally. Suddenly <reading>ketsu</reading>p (けつ) starts pouring down from the heavens.
reading_hint: This ketsup is exactly what you were looking for, but now it won't stop. You need to get out of this bind by untying the thread on your finger. But it won't budge. It's covered in ketsup. Help! You're going to drown!

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>net</radical> is for <radical>someone</radical> who works in a <kanji>government office</kanji>. You'll also take someone from a <kanji>political office</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Doesn't matter who, but you're going to catch someone from a government office using this net, it doesn't matter who.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Government office</kanji> and <kanji>political office</kanji> people put on the best <reading>show</reading>s (しょ). That's why you want to capture someone from there with your net.
reading_hint: Imagine the show they put on. You'll call your show "Exactly 8 Hours of Bureaucracy."

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> can be used for <radical>comfort</radical>, but also for <kanji>medicine</kanji>. Sure, it’s a comfort to smell flowers because they smell nice, but one can also use them as medicine to heal people.
meaning_hint: Imagine having some medicine that smells and tastes like fresh cut flowers. Smell the smell in your nose and taste the taste on your tongue.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to transport all the <kanji>medicine</kanji> on land is with a <reading>yak</reading> (やく). Yaks are big, strong, and very capable of transporting flower medicine like these.
reading_hint: Picture a yak in your mind. Pretend you are riding atop the yak as it transports this medicine. Feel the fur of the yak in your hands as you cling on for dear life.

meaning_mnemonic:
<radical>Viking</radical> <radical>see</radical>, Viking <kanji>memorize</kanji>. That’s how Vikings learn things. They see something, and then they memorize it. Quite simple, really.

It can also mean <kanji>awake</kanji>. Just remember that Vikings can't see if they aren't awake. There won't be anything to memorize if their eyes are still closed, after all!
meaning_hint: How else would a Viking memorize something? Imagine having to memorize sea charts for your Viking navigation. Look and see the maps in your brain as you memorize them.
reading_mnemonic: Every morning, a <reading>cock</reading> (かく) crows and rouses the Vikings. Seeing this, one of the Vikings <kanji>memorize</kanji>s the cock crow so that he can mimic it and play pranks on his fellow Vikings.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself memorizing the sound of a cock crow and using it to play jokes on your fellow Vikings. Cock-a-doodle-doo!

meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> <radical>sheep</radical> are <kanji>detailed</kanji> creatures. I mean, I never thought sheep were very detailed, but that’s what they say.
meaning_hint: Imagine getting really close to a sheep and seeing all the tiny detailed curls in their wool. There are hidden patterns you'd never noticed before now!
reading_mnemonic: The reason these sheep are so <kanji>detailed</kanji> is that they are trying to impress the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). If they're fancy enough, perhaps the Shougun won’t kill them for their meat and make their wool into clothing.
reading_hint: Picture the Shougun, leaning in close to inspect the detailed patterns all over the sheep. His nose is so close, he can probably smell all the little detailed nuances of the sheep's musk too.

meaning_mnemonic: What do you <radical>say</radical> to a <radical>guard</radical>? Your <kanji>theory</kanji> about how the thing he's guarding isn't even real. Yeah, you have this whole thing figured out. You have for a while. At this point, it's only fair that you tell your theory to the guard who's wasting his time.
meaning_hint: Imagine saying your theory out loud to a guard about how what he's guarding isn't even there. Imagine how he would react.
reading_mnemonic: The guard listens to your <kanji>theory</kanji> but then he says his OWN! He thinks there are two <reading>sets</reading> (せつ) of guarded items, and he's only guarding one. According to his theory, either one could be real! His theory is more plausible, don't you think?
reading_hint: Which theory do you believe? That there is nothing or that there are sets of things?

meaning_mnemonic: If you <radical>sound</radical> like a <radical>drunkard</radical> when you <radical>say</radical> things, people will not think of you as a <kanji>discerning</kanji> person. "AWh yeah, that game is greatttt," you say in your drunken slurs. But, really, it sounds like you think all games are great, which isn't all that <kanji>discriminating</kanji> of you at all.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself as a drunkard. What sort of discerning things are you saying? What are you trying to discern? Do you know?
reading_mnemonic: So, we've figured out that your drunken utterances are not very <kanji>discerning</kanji>. But let's think about someone who is discerning. You're sitting next to an extremely  <reading>chic</reading> (しき) individual, and boy do they sound like they know what they are talking about. Maybe it's because they’re not drunk like you. They are so chic and have such discerning taste!
reading_hint: Imagine the very chic person saying some very (in your eyes) discerning things about everything around them. Color yourself impressed (and feel the impressed-ness)!

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>poem</radical> about <radical>winter</radical> that you <radical>say</radical> to <kanji>warn</kanji> people against going outside. It's cold and dangerous in winter! You <kanji>admonish</kanji> anyone and everyone you see going out there with your scary winter poem.
meaning_hint: Imagine the things you'd warn people about. What is it about winter that's so dangerous?
reading_mnemonic: To make sure people listen to your <kanji>warn</kanji>ing, you threaten to take away their <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい). People will do anything for cake, so when you bring it up, they actually take your attempts to warn them about winter seriously.
reading_hint:
The winter cold will make you ache
Your whole body will start to shake
Don't go outside
I'll eat your cake

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>criminal</radical> has done an <kanji>injustice</kanji> on the world or other people. Being a criminal is a <kanji>negative</kanji> thing, and even if it was just a <kanji>mistake</kanji>, it was still a crime.
meaning_hint: Think of all the criminals you know. Even if what they did was a mistake, it was still some type of injustice, right? It was something the rest of the world sees as a negative thing.
reading_mnemonic: When you commit an <kanji>injustice</kanji>, you'll know because <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) fills your body. Maybe you've never done any kind of big thing, but when you make a <kanji>mistake</kanji> your face fills with heat and you turn red!
reading_hint: This is the heat of embarrassment, of knowing you did something negative or wrong.

meaning_mnemonic: You’re all by your lonesome <radical>self</radical> and have to check your <radical>rice paddie</radical>s, all <radical>twenty</radical> of them! Luckily, you have the most astute of all <kanji>nose</kanji>s, allowing you to quickly assess the state of your twenty rice paddies all by yourself.
meaning_hint: Really focus in on your nose. Your nostrils get huge, and your nose is huge. Smell the rice and its freshness in your imagination. Your nose is amazing.
reading_mnemonic: As you’re about to finish checking your paddies, your <kanji>nose</kanji> picks up an additional smell: It’s <reading>Hannah</reading>, bringing you a bunch of <reading>花</reading> (はな)!
reading_hint: Remember Hannah from when she helped the leader with his 花 problem? Looks like she’s brought a bunch over just for you. Really breathe in the lovely smell of the 花 deeply through your nose. Thanks Hannah!
